author: aollivierre
body:
<!--

For Windows PowerShell 5.1 issues, suggestions, or feature requests please use the following link instead:
Windows PowerShell [UserVoice](https://windowsserver.uservoice.com/forums/301869-powershell)

This repository is **ONLY** for PowerShell Core 6 issues.

- Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/known-issues-ps6?view=powershell-6).

-->

# Steps to reproduce

```powershell

after importing AzureAd module and Calling the Connect-AzureAd Cmdlet
an interactive form opens to supply credentials and provide MFA authentication 

Install-Module -Name "AzureAD" -Verbose -Force -AllowClobber
Import-Module -Name "AzureAD" -Verbose -Force
Get-Module -Name "AzureAD"-ListAvailable | Select-object Name, Version
Connect-AzureAD

```

# Expected behavior

```none

The Connect-AzureAd Cmdlet should continue successfully and establish a connection with Azure AD


```

# Actual behavior

```none

connect-azuread : One or more errors occurred. (Could not load type 'System.Security.Cryptography.SHA256Cng' from assembly 'System.Core, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089'.): Could not load type 'System.Security.Cryptography.SHA256Cng' from assembly 'System.Core, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089'.
At line:1 char:1
+ connect-azuread
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
+ CategoryInfo          : AuthenticationError: (:) [Connect-AzureAD], AadAuthenticationFailedException
+ FullyQualifiedErrorId : Connect-AzureAD,Microsoft.Open.Azure.AD.CommonLibrary.ConnectAzureAD

connect-azuread : One or more errors occurred. (Could not load type 'System.Security.Cryptography.SHA256Cng' from assembly 'System.Core, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089'.)
At line:1 char:1
+ connect-azuread
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
+ CategoryInfo          : AuthenticationError: (:) [Connect-AzureAD], AggregateException
+ FullyQualifiedErrorId : Connect-AzureAD,Microsoft.Open.Azure.AD.CommonLibrary.ConnectAzureAD

connect-azuread : Could not load type 'System.Security.Cryptography.SHA256Cng' from assembly 'System.Core, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089'.
At line:1 char:1
+ connect-azuread
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
+ CategoryInfo          : AuthenticationError: (:) [Connect-AzureAD], TypeLoadException
+ FullyQualifiedErrorId : Connect-AzureAD,Microsoft.Open.Azure.AD.CommonLibrary.ConnectAzureAD

connect-azuread : One or more errors occurred. (Could not load type 'System.Security.Cryptography.SHA256Cng' from assembly 'System.Core, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089'.): Could not load type 'System.Security.Cryptography.SHA256Cng' from assembly 'System.Core, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089'.
At line:1 char:1
+ connect-azuread
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
+ CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (:) [Connect-AzureAD], AadAuthenticationFailedException
+ FullyQualifiedErrorId : Microsoft.Open.Azure.AD.CommonLibrary.AadAuthenticationFailedException,Microsoft.Open.Azure.AD.CommonLibrary.ConnectAzureAD

```

# Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```none

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.0-preview.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.0-preview.3
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.18362
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

```

comments.author: FGRoy
comments.body:
Use: Import-Module AzureAD -UseWindowsPowerShell Until Azure Active Directory product group makes the AzureAD module compatible with PowerShell 7, we need to use the Windows PowerShell Compatibility feature. You can find more details at https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_windows_powershell_compatibility?view=powershell-7 Thanks to @alexandair [about_Windows_PowerShell_Compatibility - PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_windows_powershell_compatibility)

comments.author: joepaulk
comments.body:
You could instead try to use the az rest invoking the graph api.

Until the time az-cli is in par with the AzureAD powershell module you can instead use the graph api

```
az login --tenant <tenantname.onmicrosoft.com>
$uri = "https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/applications"

$allApplications = az rest `
   --method GET `
   --uri $uri `
   --headers 'Content-Type=application/json' | convertfrom-json

$allApplications.value |% {"{0}-{1}" -f $_.appid, $_.displayname}

```

I have put some samples using az rest here,
https://github.com/joepaulk/utilities/blob/master/manage-azuread-applicationregistrations.ps1

You may also refer to: https://damienbod.com/2020/06/22/using-azure-cli-to-create-azure-app-registrations/ from where i picked up inspiration 

Other reference, how az rest use the accesstokens from az cli can be found here, 
https://mikhail.io/2019/07/how-azure-cli-manages-access-tokens/

comments.author: macbombastic

comments.author: MaximoTrinidad
comments.body:
@macbombastic and @mpowrie 

Unfortunately, this module is not part of this repository and it's not open source.  It's owned by another team in Microsoft.

At the same time, this module will not work (yet) in PowerShell 7.x as it was built to run in Windows PowerShell: "... _The Azure AD Module is supported on the following Windows operating systems with the default version of Microsoft .NET Framework and Windows PowerShell: Windows 8.1, Windows 8, Windows 7, Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012, or Windows Server 2008 R2_... ."

In PowerShell 7.x, if you do a "Get-Module -list AzureAD", the column "PSEdition" = "Desk" (not "Core/Desk"). This means the module runs only in Windows PowerShell.

![WPoshAzureAD_01_2020-11-30_13-39-10](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/100650581-264de880-3312-11eb-88f0-32f8ce6e1db9.png)

If you go to the PowerShellGallery, look for the "Contact Owner" option to send an email message.
I know nobody likes this option but... "This is the way!".

comments.author: DEberhardt
comments.body:
From this reddit [here](https://www.reddit.com/r/PowerShell/comments/iv7cjy/connectazuread_returns_sha256cng_error_in_ps_703/), I could glean some insight:

> Windows Powershell 5.1 and Powershell Core 7 does not use the same .Net framework.
> 
> Most likely the AD module was written using the full .Net framkork for windows.
> So when you try to run i on PS 7 with the .Net Core framework it's looking for namespaces that no longer are there or named differently.
> 
> If you have 5.1 on the same box you are running PS 7 on, you can load the AD module with import-module -UseWindowsPowerShell. This will load the module in 5.1 but make it usable in 7.


Testing with `Connect-AzureAd` was successful (connection established).
`Connect-MicrosoftTeams` as well as (my) `Connect-SkypeOnline` (which calls `New-CsOnlineSession`) was unsuccessful.

comments.author: JustinGrote
comments.body:
For reference, there is an AzureAD.Preview.Standard that exists that works with .NET standard and thus Powershell 7, however it's a few versions behind and doesn't contain the latest features. https://www.poshtestgallery.com/packages/AzureAD.Standard.Preview/0.1.599.7
AzureAD.Standard.Preview 0.1.599.7
Azure Active Directory .NetStandard Preview Module. This is a Private Preview release of Azure Active Directory .NetStandard Module, available in PSGallery Internal only.

comments.author: alexandair
comments.body:
AzureAD.Preview.Standard module should not be used in production outside of the Azure Cloud Shell.
Microsoft supports it only in that environment.

comments.author: mavaddat
comments.body:
Install `AzureAD` in PowerShell 5.1.■■■■.■■■■ then, in PowerShell 7.■.■, import the module using `Import-Module AzureAD -UseWindowsPowerShell` 

```pwsh
$ Import-Module AzureAD -UseWindowsPowerShell

WARNING: Module AzureAD is loaded in Windows PowerShell using WinPSCompatSession remoting session; please note that all input and output of commands from this module will be deserialized objects. If you want to load this module into PowerShell please use 'Import-Module -SkipEditionCheck' syntax.
```

You may even get an error like this:

```pwsh
Import-Module: Failure from remote command: Import-Module -Name 'Azure': The specified module 'Azure.Storage' with version '4.3.0' was not loaded because no valid module file was found in any module directory.
```

However, it does not prevent the module cmdlets from being used in PowerShell preview.

comments.author: JustinGrote
peter-bertok
comments.body:
@JustinGrote: Am I reading that right? It's 2021, PowerShell Core has now been out for over 3 years, and yet the Azure AD team has no plan to support it?

Which of these two products is unsupported by Microsoft? AzureAD or PowerShell Core?

Because if these two technologies do not work together seamlessly, then at least one of them is _effectively_ unsupported and should not be used by anyone going forward.

Which do you recommend customers should drop?

comments.author: JustinGrote
comments.body:
I don't work for Microsoft, but I'd recommend running azureAD in PS7 using the 5.1 compatability import, and look into MS graph powershell sdk or az.resources if you need linux support, and await the new blog article the PM said he would write in regards to the azureAD future roadmap. 

Also it's just PowerShell 7 now, the "core" moniker was dropped.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body:
Complaints about AAD PowerShell module needs to go to that team. Best I can find for a repo is https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-powershell since AAD module itself isn't Open Source. As @JustinGrote politely noted, Microsoft Graph PowerShell is intended to replace AAD module. Feedback on that should be to their repo https://github.com/microsoftgraph/msgraph-sdk-powershell.
GitHub
AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-powershell
This is a repo for Azure AD PowerShell scrips and samples - AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-powershell
GitHub
microsoftgraph/msgraph-sdk-powershell
Powershell SDK for Microsoft Graph. Contribute to microsoftgraph/msgraph-sdk-powershell development by creating an account on GitHub.

title: Connect-AzureAD Could not load type 'System.Security.Cryptography.SHA256Cng' from assembly
